modules.description: Compares two values of type t using a provided comparison function and calculates the average of two values of type t to determine a midpoint. The average function ensures that for a < b, the result lies strictly between a and b. Used in tree operations to partition elements during insertion or search.

The module provides functions for constructing and manipulating decision trees, including training set management, data classification, and tree visualization, with support for both continuous and discrete features. It operates on structured data types such as training sets, decision trees, and categorized data records, enabling tasks like classification or regression. Specific use cases include building predictive models from labeled datasets and generating visual representations of tree-based decision logic.

This module enables construction and analysis of decision trees using float-based continuous data, offering tools for training set management, instance classification, and tree visualization. It works with structured datasets (`trainSet`) containing heterogeneous features and decision tree models (`decisionTree`) to represent hierarchical classification logic. Use cases include predictive modeling tasks requiring handling of mixed continuous/discrete attributes, such as medical diagnosis or financial risk assessment.

Generates decision trees from datasets using information gain ratio as the splitting criterion. Processes datasets represented as lists of labeled examples, where each example is a list of attribute values and a class label. Implements the C4.5 algorithm for classification tasks in machine learning pipelines.

The module provides operations for constructing and analyzing decision trees, including training set management, data classification, and tree visualization. It works with structured data types such as training sets, decision trees, and data vectors, supporting both continuous and discrete features for classification tasks. Use cases include building predictive models and interpreting structured datasets through tree-based representations.
